questions.text: A researcher is analyzing the results of a study comparing two antihypertensive drugs in an Indian population. She comes across the term "p-value" in her statistical analyses. Which of the following best describes the interpretation of a p-value with regard to the probability related to the null hypothesis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true

options.label: B
options.text: Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true

options.label: C
options.text: Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false

options.label: D
options.text: Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false

questions.correct_answer: B. Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true

questions.text: An investigative study was conducted in Mumbai wherein a promising new antihypertensive medication was evaluated for its potential efficacy. Initial clinical trials with a diverse cohort of patients with chronic hypertension revealed promising results in managing elevated blood pressure levels. The efficacy of the drug was measured meticulously, and upon analyzing the data, a p-value of < 0.10 was documented. Given this statistical information and considering the nuances of research interpretation, which of the following statements best elucidates the implications of this p-value in terms of the drug's effect? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance

options.label: B
options.text: 90% of patients will be benefitted by giving the drug

options.label: D
options.text: 90% of test results could have occurred by chance

questions.correct_answer: A. Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The p-value is a statistical parameter used to evaluate whether the results of an experiment are statistically significant. In this case, a p-value of < 0.10 suggests there is up to a 10% chance that the observed benefits from the antihypertensive drug could be due to random variation rather than a true effect of the drug.
  • ➤ The p-value is a statistical parameter used to evaluate whether the results of an experiment are statistically significant.
  • ➤ In this case, a p-value of < 0.10 suggests there is up to a 10% chance that the observed benefits from the antihypertensive drug could be due to random variation rather than a true effect of the drug.

questions.text: Which of the following steps is not included in WHO's STEP approach?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Therapeutic assessment

questions.text: Which of the following statistical tools is most suitable for establishing the optimal cutoff point to distinguish between positive and negative test results? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Receiver-operating characteristic (ROC) curve: An ROC curve plots the true positive rate (sensitivity) against the false positive rate (1-specificity) for different test result cut-off points. It allows for the visualization of the trade-off between sensitivity and specificity at various thresholds. The optimal threshold is often chosen based on the point on the curve closest to the top-left corner (maximizing true positives while minimizing false positives) or by considering the specific clinical context and the relative importance of sensitivity and specificity.
  • • Receiver-operating characteristic (ROC) curve: An ROC curve plots the true positive rate (sensitivity) against the false positive rate (1-specificity) for different test result cut-off points. It allows for the visualization of the trade-off between sensitivity and specificity at various thresholds. The optimal threshold is often chosen based on the point on the curve closest to the top-left corner (maximizing true positives while minimizing false positives) or by considering the specific clinical context and the relative importance of sensitivity and specificity.
  • • Receiver-operating characteristic (ROC) curve:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Analysis of variance (ANOVA): ANOVA is used to compare means between three or more groups. It is not relevant to determining the diagnostic threshold for a test. Option B. Pearson coefficient: The Pearson correlation coefficient measures the linear relationship between two continuous variables. It does not directly help in setting the threshold for a diagnostic test. Option D. Pre-test probability: This is the estimated likelihood of a patient having the condition before the test is conducted. While it can influence the interpretation of test results, it doesn't help in determining the optimal threshold itself.
  • • Option A. Analysis of variance (ANOVA): ANOVA is used to compare means between three or more groups. It is not relevant to determining the diagnostic threshold for a test.
  • • Option A. Analysis of variance (ANOVA):
  • • Option B. Pearson coefficient: The Pearson correlation coefficient measures the linear relationship between two continuous variables. It does not directly help in setting the threshold for a diagnostic test.
  • • Option B. Pearson coefficient:
  • • Option D. Pre-test probability: This is the estimated likelihood of a patient having the condition before the test is conducted. While it can influence the interpretation of test results, it doesn't help in determining the optimal threshold itself.
  • • Option D. Pre-test probability:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ROC curve is the most appropriate tool for determining the optimal threshold for a diagnostic test, as it allows for the visualization and balancing of sensitivity and specificity at different cutoff points.
  • ➤ The ROC curve is the most appropriate tool for determining the optimal threshold for a diagnostic test, as it allows for the visualization and balancing of sensitivity and specificity at different cutoff points.

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hall-Wellner Band

questions.text: As a medical student, you're learning about the margin of error and its relationship with sample size. With three studies of different sizes (Sample 1: 1000, Sample 2: 800, Sample 3: 600), how would you order the expected margins of error from largest to smallest? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 3>2>1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The margin of error in a study is inversely related to the square root of the sample size. This relationship implies that a larger sample size will generally lead to a smaller margin of error, assuming other variables like variance remain constant.
  • ➤ The margin of error in a study is inversely related to the square root of the sample size.
  • ➤ This relationship implies that a larger sample size will generally lead to a smaller margin of error, assuming other variables like variance remain constant.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of stage IV non-small cell lung cancer presents with worsening dyspnea, non-productive cough, and uncontrolled pain despite current medication. He has declined further aggressive treatment. What stands true for Palliative care? (INICET NOV 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: To improve quality of life patient

options.label: D
options.text: Nothing is done in palliative care

questions.correct_answer: C. To improve quality of life patient
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) To improve quality of life patient

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Palliative care is a specialized medical care focused on providing relief from the symptoms and stress of a serious illness.
  • • The primary goal of palliative care is to improve the quality of life for the patient . It involves treating pain and other distressing symptoms, providing psychological and spiritual care, and supporting the patient and their family to cope with the challenges of a serious illness.
  • • to improve the quality of life for the patient
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. To cure disease : This is incorrect. Palliative care does not aim to cure the underlying disease but focuses on alleviating symptoms and improving the quality of life for both the patient and their family.
  • • Option A. To cure disease
  • • Option B. Do nothing to prolong life : Palliative care does not necessarily aim to prolong life, nor does it hasten death. It’s about enhancing the quality of life and may also indirectly prolong it by improving general health and well-being.
  • • Option B. Do nothing to prolong life
  • • Option D. Nothing is done in palliative care : This is incorrect. Palliative care involves active and comprehensive management of various issues that arise with serious illnesses, including physical, emotional, social, and spiritual aspects of care.
  • • Option D. Nothing is done in palliative care

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Palliative care is crucial for improving the quality of life for patients with serious illnesses. It addresses a wide range of needs, ensuring the patient’s comfort and supporting the family through difficult times, emphasizing symptom management and personal support over curative treatments.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman delivers her baby in a public hospital in a rural district in India. She is informed by the healthcare provider that she will receive free transportation, medications, and diet during her hospital stay for both herself and her newborn. The provider further explains that this is part of a program introduced in 2011 under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) to ensure better health outcomes for mothers and newborns by expanding the scope of an earlier program, which initially focused only on maternal health. Which of the following programs is most likely being referred to?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) , launched on June 1, 2011, under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), provides free and cashless services to pregnant women and their newborns, including free transport, medications, and diet. JSSK was introduced as an extension of the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) , which originally focused only on maternal health. JSSK expanded the scope to include newborn care up to 1 year of age, recognizing the need for comprehensive care for both mothers and infants.
  • • Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK)
  • • Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) National Maternity Benefit Scheme (NMBS): This program was the predecessor to the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) . While NMBS provided financial assistance to pregnant women, it did not offer the broad range of free services that JSSK provides for both mothers and newborns.
  • • Option
  • • A) National Maternity Benefit Scheme (NMBS):
  • • Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)
  • • Option C) Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK): RBSK is a child health program that focuses on early identification and management of health conditions in children up to 18 years of age. It is not designed specifically for maternal and newborn care.
  • • Option
  • • C) Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK):
  • • Option D) Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS): ICDS focuses on improving the nutrition and health of children up to 6 years of age, as well as pregnant and lactating mothers, but it does not provide free medical services for deliveries like JSSK.
  • • Option
  • • D) Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) provides free and cashless healthcare services to pregnant women and newborns in public health facilities, including transportation, medications, and diet. It was introduced in 2011 to extend the focus of the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) , which was initially aimed only at maternal health.
  • ➤ Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK)
  • ➤ Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)

questions.text: A 40-year-old nurse in the infectious diseases ward is reviewing the necessary precautions for attending to patients with various primary diagnoses. For which of the following patients would she NOT need to take special airborne precautions? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Herpes Zoster

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles, Tuberculosis, and chickenpox require airborne transmission precaution unlike herpes zoster. The patient should be made to wear a mask for source control. A fit-tested NIOSH-approved N95 or higher-level respirator should be used by the healthcare personnel whilst care delivery.
  • ➤ Measles, Tuberculosis, and chickenpox require airborne transmission precaution unlike herpes zoster.
  • ➤ The patient should be made to wear a mask for source control.
  • ➤ A fit-tested NIOSH-approved N95 or higher-level respirator should be used by the healthcare personnel whilst care delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Early diagnosis and treatment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early diagnosis and treatment (secondary prevention) are the most effective methods for preventing the progression of breast cancer, as they allow for early detection and intervention, significantly improving the chances of successful treatment and reducing mortality rates.

questions.text: A medical student accidentally drops a sphygmomanometer, causing mercury spill on the floor. What is the most appropriate method to manage this spill? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Collect using your hand and discard in drain

options.label: B
options.text: Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket

options.label: C
options.text: Collect and throw outside in the environment

options.label: D
options.text: Broom it and discard in dustbin

questions.correct_answer: B. Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate method to manage a mercury spill is to collect it using paper/cardboard and place it in a water tube or bucket, then ensure safe and proper disposal. Avoid direct contact, vacuuming, or sweeping the mercury.
  • ➤ The most appropriate method to manage a mercury spill is to collect it using paper/cardboard and place it in a water tube or bucket, then ensure safe and proper disposal.
  • ➤ Avoid direct contact, vacuuming, or sweeping the mercury.

questions.explanation:

questions.text: You're mentoring a group of budding epidemiologists who are keen on understanding the nuances of different study designs. One of them is particularly interested in case-control studies. During your discussion, you decide to quiz them on aspects that are typically not inherent to case-control studies. Which of the given options would not usually be part of a case-control study? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Follow up

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Case-control studies do not include follow-up of subjects but focus on matching, assessing the strength of association using odds ratios, and selecting cases and controls for analysis.
  • ➤ Case-control studies do not include follow-up of subjects but focus on matching, assessing the strength of association using odds ratios, and selecting cases and controls for analysis.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting an experiment in a controlled climate room to measure the air velocity. To assess the cooling effect of the air, the researcher uses an instrument that cools based on the surrounding air movement. What is the name of this instrument, as shown below?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Kata thermometer is an instrument traditionally used to measure the cooling power of air, particularly in moving air environments. It works by measuring how quickly it cools down when exposed to airflow. In modern times, the Kata thermometer is more commonly used to assess low air velocity, determining the rate of heat loss in still air. It is particularly useful in controlled climates or laboratory conditions for evaluating air movement.
  • • Kata thermometer
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Anemometer: An anemometer is used to measure wind speed or air velocity, typically in outdoor environments, but it does not measure cooling effects like the Kata thermometer.
  • • Option A) Anemometer:
  • • Option C) Barometer: A barometer measures atmospheric pressure, not air velocity or cooling power.
  • • Option C) Barometer:
  • • Option D) Hygrometer: A hygrometer is used to measure humidity levels in the air, not the cooling power or air velocity.
  • • Option D) Hygrometer:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Kata thermometer is used to measure the cooling power of air or low air velocity by determining the rate of heat loss. It is commonly used in laboratories or controlled climate settings.
  • ➤ Kata thermometer

questions.text: A community with a population of 20,000 documented 456 births in a year, of which 56 were stillbirths. The total number of deaths in the community for that year was 247, including 56 deaths within the first 28 days of life and 34 additional deaths after 28 days but before completing the first year of life. What is the infant mortality rate (IMR) for this community? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 225

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) for the community, calculated as the number of infant deaths per 1000 live births. This rate serves as a crucial indicator of the health status and effectiveness of maternal and child health services in the community.
  • ➤ The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) for the community, calculated as the number of infant deaths per 1000 live births.
  • ➤ This rate serves as a crucial indicator of the health status and effectiveness of maternal and child health services in the community.
  • ➤ NOTE - UNICEF considers U5MR or CMR as ‘single best indicator of socio-economic development and well-being’ (even better than IMR)
  • ➤ NOTE - UNICEF considers U5MR or CMR as ‘single best indicator of socio-economic development and well-being’ (even better than IMR)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. During the social history taking, she mentions that she has started engaging in certain behaviors and rituals that align with her new community after recently moving to a different country. What is the term for this type of behavior acquisition? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Socialization

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Learning and try to adapt to new community. This is known as Socialization
  • • Socialization is the process by which individuals learn and adopt the norms, values, and behaviors appropriate to their society. Socialization is key in helping individuals function as members of their society, and it involves learning the language, norms, and rituals of the community. This term directly applies to the scenario described, as the woman is adopting behaviors that align with her new community.
  • • Socialization
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Custom : This term refers to a traditional and widely accepted way of behaving or doing something that is specific to a particular society, place, or time. Customs are the established patterns of behavior that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting
  • • Option A. Custom
  • • Option B. Culture : Is the learned behavior which is socially acquired. Culture is a broader term that includes knowledge, belief systems, art, morals, laws, and any other capabilities and habits acquired by individuals as members of society.
  • • Option B. Culture
  • • Option D. Mores : These are the moral norms, manners, or customs that are considered important for the welfare of a community and are enforced by social disapproval or formal sanctions if violated. Mores are a subset of social norms that include strong moral connotations and are seen as foundational to societal welfare.
  • • Option D. Mores

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ "Socialization" best captures the process the woman is undergoing as she adopts the practices of her new community.

questions.text: A study was carried out in three different states to analyze the average blood pressure within each community. Health workers were assigned to visit every household in these communities, and the mean blood pressure for each community was then calculated and compared. What study design best describes this research approach? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cross-sectional study: A cross-sectional study examines a population at a single point in time. It captures a snapshot of the population's characteristics, including health outcomes like blood pressure, at that specific moment. The study described in the question aligns with this definition as health workers collected blood pressure data from individuals in different communities at one particular time.
  • • Cross-sectional study: A cross-sectional study examines a population at a single point in time. It captures a snapshot of the population's characteristics, including health outcomes like blood pressure, at that specific moment. The study described in the question aligns with this definition as health workers collected blood pressure data from individuals in different communities at one particular time.
  • • Cross-sectional study:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Cohort study: A cohort study involves following a group of individuals over time to observe the development of outcomes. This study does not involve any follow-up period. Option C. Field trial: Field trials are interventional studies conducted on healthy individuals to assess the effectiveness of preventive measures. This study doesn't involve any intervention. Option D. Case-control study: A case-control study starts with individuals who have a specific outcome (cases) and compares them to those without the outcome (controls) to identify potential risk factors. This study design is not applicable here.
  • • Option A. Cohort study: A cohort study involves following a group of individuals over time to observe the development of outcomes. This study does not involve any follow-up period.
  • • Option A. Cohort study:
  • • Option C. Field trial: Field trials are interventional studies conducted on healthy individuals to assess the effectiveness of preventive measures. This study doesn't involve any intervention.
  • • Option C. Field trial:
  • • Option D. Case-control study: A case-control study starts with individuals who have a specific outcome (cases) and compares them to those without the outcome (controls) to identify potential risk factors. This study design is not applicable here.
  • • Option D. Case-control study:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A cross-sectional study is an observational study design that assesses a population at a specific point in time. It is often used to estimate the prevalence of a health condition or risk factor
  • ➤ A cross-sectional study is an observational study design that assesses a population at a specific point in time. It is often used to estimate the prevalence of a health condition or risk factor

  • ➤ Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation
  • ➤ Rifampicin inhibit RNA polymerase

questions.text: A neurology resident is assessing a patient with a recent traumatic brain injury and uses the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) to evaluate the patient’s level of consciousness and neurological responses. During a teaching session, the resident asks a medical student about the nature of the data generated by the GCS and how it should be interpreted in terms of data classification. What type of data does the GCS score represent?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to assess the level of consciousness in patients with brain injury by assigning scores to eye, verbal, and motor responses. These scores are then summed to classify the severity of the injury into mild, moderate, or severe categories. The GCS score is an example of ordinal data because the categories follow a specific order or rank (i.e., increasing severity), but the differences between scores are not necessarily equal or measurable in precise terms.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Nominal Scale: Nominal scales classify data into distinct categories without any order or ranking. Examples include variables like gender, blood type, or race, which do not have a specific sequence or hierarchy. The GCS does not fall under this category because it involves a ranked classification.
  • • Option
  • • A. Nominal Scale:
  • • Option C. Metric Scale: Metric scales involve quantitative measurements that have equal intervals between values, such as weight, height, or temperature. This scale is used for continuous data where precise measurements can be made. The GCS is not metric because its scores are ranked but not measured with equal intervals.
  • • Option
  • • C. Metric Scale:
  • • Option D. Nominal Categorical Scale: Nominal categorical scales involve qualitative data classified into groups without any inherent order, similar to the nominal scale. The GCS score, however, involves a ranking order, making this an incorrect classification.
  • • Option
  • • D. Nominal Categorical Scale:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) produces ordinal data as it classifies the severity of brain injury in a ranked order, such as mild, moderate, or severe. Understanding the nature of the data type generated by clinical assessment tools like the GCS helps in appropriate data analysis and interpretation in clinical practice.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of hands with stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient's hands is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid Arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rheumatoid Arthritis is suggested by the presence of symmetrical small joint pain and stiffness, particularly in the morning, with potential visible joint deformities. Early and aggressive treatment is vital to manage symptoms and prevent progressive joint damage.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/RA/Chap

questions.text: Which of the below is the most preferred investigation for parathyroid adenoma localisation? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sestamibi SPECT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While all these methods can assist in the diagnosis and localization of parathyroid adenomas, Sestamibi SPECT is generally considered the most effective standalone imaging modality due to its high specificity for active parathyroid tissue and its ability to provide detailed spatial resolution. It is particularly valuable in surgical planning to ensure precise removal of the adenoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with complaints of persistent abdominal pain and altered bowel movements. On performing a colonoscopy, a carcinoma of the colon was detected. The biopsy report showed the presence of gene mutations in the tumor tissue. What are the common gene mutations seen in carcinoma of the colon? ( INICET May 2020)

questions.text: Most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Granisetron, a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, is the most effective antiemetic for preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). It is the standard of care for managing nausea and vomiting associated with moderate to highly emetogenic chemotherapy agents.

questions.text: A Patient came with sudden onset palpitations. ECG showed narrow complex, regular tachycardia without P waves, and a rate of 160bpm. His BP is 96/68mmHg. What is the next step in management? (AIIMS NOV 2018)

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presented with generalized weakness, which increased towards the evening and improved with 5-10 minutes of rest in between. On examination, he also had ptosis and some difficulty in swallowing. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Myasthenia Gravis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. Key clinical features include ptosis, difficulty swallowing, and generalized weakness with a diurnal variation.
  • ➤ Most sensitive diagnosis is supported by single fiber EMG and most specific investigation is antibody tests, such as acetylcholine receptor antibodies and anti-muscle specific kinase antibodies.

questions.text: The catalytic efficiency of enzyme is best expressed by which of the following kinetic constants? ( AIIMS May 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Kcat/Km

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The catalytic efficiency of an enzyme is best expressed by the ratio Kcat/Km, as it provides a measure of how effectively the enzyme converts substrate into product, considering both the enzyme's turnover rate and its substrate affinity.

questions.text: Dr. Rajan, a consultant at a primary health center, often manages sexually transmitted infections (STIs) using a syndromic approach due to limited diagnostic facilities. A 28-year-old male patient presents with urethral discharge, painful urination, and mild scrotal swelling but denies any history of systemic symptoms such as fever. On examination, there is no significant inguinal lymphadenopathy. Given the patient's symptoms and the need to address both gonococcal and non-gonococcal causes of urethritis without specific laboratory tests, which of the following medication combinations would be the most appropriate for syndromic management?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The syndromic approach to managing STIs/RTIs particularly in settings with limited diagnostic capacity, involves treating the most common causative agents based on the presenting symptoms. For urethral discharge, the treatment needs to cover both gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis. The combination of Azithromycin and Cefixime is recommended because Azithromycin is effective against Chlamydia trachomatis, while Cefixime is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This combination provides broad coverage, addressing the most common bacterial causes of urethritis.
  • • Azithromycin
  • • Cefixime
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Azithromycin and Doxycycline While Azithromycin covers non-gonococcal causes like Chlamydia, Doxycycline is also effective against Chlamydia but does not adequately cover gonococcal infections. Therefore, it is not the best choice for treating gonococcal urethritis.
  • • Option A. Azithromycin and Doxycycline
  • • Option B. Cefixime and Metronidazole Cefixime is effective against gonorrhea; however, Metronidazole is primarily used for anaerobic infections and trichomoniasis and does not cover non-gonococcal urethritis effectively. This combination would miss Chlamydia, a common cause of urethritis.
  • • Option B. Cefixime and Metronidazole
  • • Option D. Penicillin and Fluconazole Penicillin has limited efficacy against modern strains of gonorrhea due to resistance, and Fluconazole is used for fungal infections such as candidiasis, which is not relevant in this case. This combination does not appropriately address the bacterial causes of urethritis.
  • • Option D. Penicillin and Fluconazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The syndromic management of STIs/RTIs
  • ➤ especially in resource-limited settings, involves the use of broad-spectrum treatment targeting the most likely pathogens. For urethral discharge, the combination of Azithromycin and Cefixime covers both gonococcal and non-gonococcal infections, ensuring comprehensive care without specific pathogen identification.

questions.text: Basophils are activated by? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IL-5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Interleukins are a type of cytokine, which are small proteins produced by immune cells that play a crucial role in regulating the immune response.
  • ➤ A brief overview of some of the key interleukins and their functions:
  • ➤ Interleukin-1 (IL-1): This interleukin is involved in the regulation of inflammation and immune responses, as well as activation of immune cells such as T cells and B cells. Interleukin-2 (IL-2): This cytokine is primarily produced by T cells and plays a key role in the activation and proliferation of T cells and natural killer (NK) cells. It is also involved in the differentiation of immune cells, such as the development of memory T cells. Interleukin-4 (IL-4): Plays a key role in the development of Th2 cells, which are involved in the immune response to parasites and allergies. IL-4 also stimulates the production of antibodies by B cells. Interleukin-5 (IL-5): S pecifically activates basophils, contributing to their role in allergic responses and inflammation. Interleukin-6 (IL-6): Plays a key role in the regulation of inflammation and immune responses. It can stimulate the production of acute-phase proteins, such as C-reactive protein, as well as the activation of immune cells like plasma cells. Interleukin-10 (IL-10) : Plays a key role in regulating the immune response and limiting inflammation. It can suppress the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, as well as the activation of immune cells. Interleukin-12 (IL-12 ): IL-12 is involved in the activation of T cells and NK cells. It can stimulate the differentiation of Th1 cells, which are involved in the immune response to intracellular pathogens.
  • ➤ Interleukin-1 (IL-1): This interleukin is involved in the regulation of inflammation and immune responses, as well as activation of immune cells such as T cells and B cells.
  • ➤ Interleukin-1 (IL-1):
  • ➤ Interleukin-2 (IL-2): This cytokine is primarily produced by T cells and plays a key role in the activation and proliferation of T cells and natural killer (NK) cells. It is also involved in the differentiation of immune cells, such as the development of memory T cells.
  • ➤ Interleukin-2 (IL-2):
  • ➤ Interleukin-4 (IL-4): Plays a key role in the development of Th2 cells, which are involved in the immune response to parasites and allergies. IL-4 also stimulates the production of antibodies by B cells.
  • ➤ Interleukin-4 (IL-4):
  • ➤ Interleukin-5 (IL-5): S pecifically activates basophils, contributing to their role in allergic responses and inflammation.
  • ➤ Interleukin-5 (IL-5): S
  • ➤ Interleukin-6 (IL-6): Plays a key role in the regulation of inflammation and immune responses. It can stimulate the production of acute-phase proteins, such as C-reactive protein, as well as the activation of immune cells like plasma cells.
  • ➤ Interleukin-6 (IL-6):
  • ➤ Interleukin-10 (IL-10) : Plays a key role in regulating the immune response and limiting inflammation. It can suppress the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, as well as the activation of immune cells.
  • ➤ Interleukin-10 (IL-10)
  • ➤ Interleukin-12 (IL-12 ): IL-12 is involved in the activation of T cells and NK cells. It can stimulate the differentiation of Th1 cells, which are involved in the immune response to intracellular pathogens.
  • ➤ Interleukin-12 (IL-12

questions.text: A 56-year-old male recently diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma, with imaging indicating a tumor size less than 4 cm, what would be the most suitable initial treatment approach for this patient's condition among the following options? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Partial nephrectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Partial nephrectomy is the recommended initial treatment for renal cell carcinoma tumors less than 4 cm in diameter (Stage T1a), as it aims to remove the tumor while preserving as much kidney function as possible. This approach balances oncological control with the preservation of renal function.

questions.text: Match the wood lamp findings with the respective diseases: (INICET MAY 2023)

The specific color of fluorescence can guide clinicians in making a preliminary diagnosis, which must be confirmed with additional tests or clinical evaluation.

questions.text: Which of the following childhood injuries will lead to a fish tail injury? ( INICET May 2020)

questions.text: During a global health conference, a public health professional is discussing various measures used to assess the development and well-being of countries. She emphasizes the importance of understanding the components of widely recognized indices such as the Human Development Index (HDI). A medical student asks for clarification on what constitutes the HDI and its significance in comparing global health standards. Which of the following best describes the components that make up the Human Development Index?

options.label: A
options.text: Life expectancy at 1-year age, Infant mortality rate, and Literacy rate

options.label: B
options.text: Life expectancy at birth, Income, and Knowledge

options.label: C
options.text: Real GDP per capita, Health expenditure, and School enrolment ratio

options.label: D
options.text: Infant mortality rate, Gross National Income, and Education index

questions.correct_answer: B. Life expectancy at birth, Income, and Knowledge
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite measure used to assess the development status of countries by combining three main components: longevity (life expectancy at birth), income (measured by real GDP per capita in purchasing power parity, PPP, US$), and knowledge (mean years of schooling and literacy rate). This index provides a more comprehensive view of a country's development compared to economic measures alone, as it considers health, education, and income dimensions.
  • • Human Development Index (HDI)
  • • Components Of HDI AND PQLI:
  • • Components Of HDI AND PQLI:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Life expectancy at 1-year age, Infant mortality rate, and Literacy rate This combination describes the components of the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI), not HDI. PQLI includes life expectancy at oneyear, infant mortality rate, and literacy rate.
  • • Option A. Life expectancy at 1-year age, Infant mortality rate, and Literacy rate
  • • Option C. Real GDP per capita, Health expenditure, and School enrollment ratio These indicators are related to economic and educational measures but do not encompass all three dimensions specifically used in the HDI calculation.
  • • Option C. Real GDP per capita, Health expenditure, and School enrollment ratio
  • • Option D. Infant mortality rate, Gross National Income, and Education index This combination includes related but incorrect components; infant mortality rate is not part of HDI, which focuses on life expectancy instead.
  • • Option D. Infant mortality rate, Gross National Income, and Education index

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Human Development Index (HDI) evaluates a country's overall development by incorporating health, education, and income metrics. HDI uses life expectancy at birth, GDP per capita adjusted for purchasing power, and education measures (mean years of schooling and literacy rate) to provide a broader view of human development beyond economic performance alone.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod-human transmission route? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Japanese encephalitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The transmission cycles of diseases like Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective public health measures. In the case of JE, controlling mosquito populations and minimizing human exposure to mosquito bites, especially in areas where birds are present, are key strategies in preventing the disease.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding the course of the mandibular nerve? (INICET NOV 2022) Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint. Buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct. Ophthalmic nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arises in the middle cranial fossa.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 2,3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Correct Statements:
  • • Correct Statements:
  • • Statement 2 : True. The buccal branch, which is indeed a branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, emerges from behind the mandibular ramus. This nerve primarily supplies sensory innervation to the skin over the cheek and buccal mucosa.
  • • Statement 2
  • • Statement 3: True. The lingual nerve, a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It famously arcs around the submandibular duct, a notable anatomical feature.
  • • Statement 3:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Statement 1 : Incorrect. The auriculotemporal nerve actually arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, not the anterior division, and it does indeed emerge from behind the temporomandibular joint.
  • • Statement 1
  • • Statement 4: Incorrect. The ophthalmic nerve is not a branch of the mandibular nerve. Instead, it is an independent division of the trigeminal nerve (V1), originating from the trigeminal ganglion located in the middle cranial fossa. It is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the forehead, scalp, and parts of the eye.
  • • Statement 4:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The mandibular nerve's complex branching includes both sensory and motor components that are essential for facial sensation and movements. Understanding its branches, such as the buccal and lingual nerves, and their courses, is critical in dental, surgical, and diagnostic practices.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used for induction of anesthesia, maintenance and can be safely used in endotracheal intubation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Sevoflurane

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sevoflurane is a versatile inhalation anesthetic that can be used for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia. Its sweet smell makes it suitable for inhalational induction, especially in pediatric patients and others who might find pungent agents unpleasant. Sevoflurane also provides a smooth transition for endotracheal intubation due to its bronchodilatory effects and stable hemodynamic profile. Additionally, its low blood-gas solubility coefficient allows for rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia, which is beneficial in a surgical setting.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Halothane: While Halothane can be used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia, it has a higher risk of hepatotoxicity and arrhythmias. It is also less commonly used in modern practice compared to Sevoflurane.
  • • Option A. Halothane:
  • • Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is typically used for maintenance rather than induction due to its pungent odor and tendency to cause airway irritation. It also requires a special heated vaporizer due to its high vapor pressure.
  • • Option B. Desflurane:
  • • Option D. Isoflurane : Isoflurane is primarily used for maintenance of anesthesia rather than induction due to its pungent smell and potential to cause airway irritation. It is less suitable for inhalational induction compared to Sevoflurane.
  • • Option D. Isoflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Sevoflurane is an ideal agent for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia and is safe for use during endotracheal intubation due to its favorable properties.

questions.text: A patient presents with flu-like symptoms after a camping trip and multiple insect bites. You suspect a vector-borne illness. Which pathogen is likely if the vector is a Trombiculid mite? (AIIMS NOV 2019)

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with follicular tonsillitis, for which antibiotics were prescribed. In a few days, the child developed flank pain and rash. Peripheral blood demonstrated eosinophilia, and urinalysis showed WBC casts. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allergic interstitial nephritis is characterized by recent medication use (such as antibiotics), flank pain, rash, eosinophilia, and WBC casts in urine. It is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by drugs, particularly antibiotics.
